Some shocking figures were released this week in an Institute of Physics (IOP) Report looking at the progression of girls going on to study A level physics. Rather than just concentrating on the percentage of girls taking the subject, which is well known to hover just below 30%, the study analysed the progression of girls from different types of school.

Overall 46% of schools did not send a single girl on to A level physics, and if only coeducational schools in the maintained sector were considered the figure was even higher, at 49%. Put another way, nearly half of the mixed, state schools in England did not manage to enthuse their girls sufficiently to make any one of them wish to take physics at A level.

It's no secret that many physics teachers do not actually have physics degrees, but if teachers who were lacking confidence and skill in the subject were the only reason for the poor progression, one would expect the figures for boys to be comparable. Not so: only 12% of co-ed maintained schools failed to send any boys on to A level. As the title of the report makes clear, It's Different for Girls. What the report on its own cannot identify is precisely why this might be so, but this is a state of play that should not and must not be allowed to continue for generation after generation.

The argument that is so often advanced is that, for whatever reason, girls just don't "like" physics. I would contend that the data (also contained in this report) which show that single-sex girls' schools manage to send 2.5 times as many girls on as mixed schools, disproves that argument. However much single-sex schools may have some systematic differences from co-ed ones, I do not believe these differences on their own are sufficiently significant to lead to that enormous difference in numbers. Something in the ethos and environment of many coeducational establishments is coming into play and discouraging many girls from seeing physics as a suitable topic to take at A level.

This does not require teachers to be consciously dissuading the girls from thinking about the subject seriously, so much as permitting a culture in which the message is received that somehow it is "odd" for girls to be interested in space, machines and machinery, atoms or any of the other exciting topics that lurk in physics. This is a message that may well be reinforced by parents and seems pervasive in the media.

Teenagers are very sensitive to subtle cues about what is "acceptable", and can take such hints to heart and act upon them. In other words, the fact that there are currently low numbers of women physicists so that they are seen as a rarity if not an oddity, means that the visible stereotype is a male. It is all too easy for teachers (of any subject) and peers to reinforce the stereotype and steer girls into subjects perceived as more normal or acceptable. Hence we continue to see the majority of girls who opt for one or more science A levels flocking to biology rather than physics, whereas the number of boys who do one or other of those subjects is pretty much equal.

When I was on the Today programme this week talking about this report, my fellow interviewee was a female head teacher who objected strongly to any notion that a teacher would explicitly tell a girl not to do physics (although I had not suggested this might happen). A little later she went on to produce the argument that maybe girls don't want to do physics. By voicing that assumption she seems to me to be dangerously close to unconsciously reinforcing the stereotype.

It is of course not just the teachers who may be giving off negative messages; the boys in a class can play at least as large a role. How often have girls been told by boys that physics is not for them? Or that they'll never get a boyfriend if they are so unfeminine as to like physics? Or, perhaps worst of all, that it isn't cool for a girl to enjoy the subject. I fear many, many women who have stuck with the subject could name frequent occasions when some such similar remark was levelled at them. But how many more girls face this sort of disparagement and give up?

Teachers collectively need to make sure, not only that their own actions and words do not discourage, but that they stamp on casual sexist remarks from the boys. Only by such zero tolerance in schools, creating a solid ethos of support for girls to pursue whatever they genuinely are interested in, will we discover what percentage of girls really would like to take physics A level. The IOP report makes it very hard to believe we can accurately assess that figure yet, let alone that we have reached it.

Parents can do their bit, both by ensuring from birth they do not project gender stereotypes and also challenging schools about their own statistics. Few parents may know what their daughters are interested in when they look around to choose a secondary school, but it would help to keep the pressure up if they asked questions about each school's record as regards the subjects girls choose to proceed with to A level. The schools inspectorate Ofsted may also have a role to play in ensuring that gender equity is considered during inspections.

The full list of recommendations that the IOP proposes can be seen in its report.

Why does any of this matter? I would suggest there are three reasons. First, it is a matter of natural justice. If the current system is essentially disenfranchising large numbers of girls from considering physics seriously as a suitable subject for them, we are not treating them fairly.

Second, as a report from the Royal Academy of Engineering demonstrated this week, we are not producing a sufficient number of Stem (Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics) graduates to satisfy the needs of employers and the economy. The academy's main focus is on engineering, for which physics A level would be a standard prerequisite. If we are losing, quite unnecessarily, a substantial fraction of each year's cohort from gaining a qualification in physics, there is an easy way of increasing the pool by making sure that all girls get that opportunity.

Finally, as with boards of directors, or teams more generally, diversity can be a positive influence on outcome – be it profit, innovation or some other metric. Let's make sure we do all we can as a nation to foster a diverse pool of talent from which which engineering and physics employers can draw, facilitating real diversity and thereby creativity.

As things stand, I – as that rather odd thing a female professor of physics – would argue we collectively need to do much more to give all our female children genuine equality of opportunity at school. That includes ensuring that no subject is conveyed as being inappropriate. In that case maybe finally, a female physicist will no longer be regarded as peculiar.

Athene Donald is a professor of physics at the University of Cambridge and a fellow of the Institute of Physics

Strong economic growth in the past decade among African countries rich in oil and minerals has failed to make a significant dent on their poverty levels, according to a World Bank report.

Africa's Pulse, a twice-yearly analysis of Africa's economic prospects, noted that the decline in poverty rates in resource-rich countries has generally lagged behind that of countries without riches in the ground. Some countries, such as Angola, Congo-Brazzaville and Gabon, have witnessed an increase in the percentage of the population living in extreme poverty.

The report confirms the common perception that, to a large extent, the benefits of growth have not reached the poorest segments of society. It raises questions for aid donors and African governments on how to deal with the "resource curse", with strikes in South African mines providing a stark illustration of what is at stake.

"Resource-rich African countries have to make the conscious choice to invest in better health, education, and jobs, and less poverty for their people, because it will not happen automatically when countries strike it rich," said Shantayanan Devarajan, the World Bank's chief economist for Africa, and lead author of Africa's Pulse. "Gabon, for example, with a per-capita income of $10,000 (£6,200) has one of the lowest child immunisation rates in Africa."

How to ensure that natural resources benefit the general population, not just the elite, is a question likely to grow more acute as discoveries of oil, gas and other minerals in African countries are expected to generate considerable wealth in the future.

The region's established oil producers represent less than 10% of the share of both global reserves and annual production. Nigeria, Africa's biggest oil producer, can keep supplying at 2011 levels for another 41 years, while Angola, the second largest producer in the region, has about 21 years remaining at current production levels before its known reserves are depleted.

With such sizeable reserves, it is likely the dependence on oil resources in these countries will continue. Production in new mineral countries such as Ghana, Mozambique, Sierra Leone and Uganda could last for a substantial number of years.

Others have considerable mineral resources. In 2010, Guinea represented more than 8% of total world bauxite production; Zambia and the Democratic Republic of the Congo have a combined share of 6.7% of the total world copper production; and Ghana and Mali together account for 5.8% of total world gold production.

Africa's Pulse underlines the continent's heavy dependence on commodities for its recent growth, although domestic demand has played its part. Sub-Saharan Africa is expected to grow at 4.8% in 2012, broadly unchanged from 4.9% growth in 2011, and is largely on track despite setbacks in the global economy. Excluding South Africa, the continent's largest economy, growth in sub-Saharan Africa is forecast to rise to 6%.

While African economies have not been immune to the crisis in the eurozone, the World Bank said consistently high commodity prices and strong export growth in countries with mineral discoveries in recent years have fuelled economic activity and are expected to underpin economic growth for the rest of the year.

A measure of the continent's economic success is strong investor interest. "An important indicator of how Africa is on the move is that investor interest in the region remains strong, with $31bn in foreign direct investment flows expected this year, despite difficult global conditions," said Makhtar Diop, World Bank vice-president for Africa.

The report noted that, after 10 years of high growth, an increasing number of countries are moving into "middle-income" status, defined as those countries reaching more than $1,000 per-capita income. Of 48 countries, 22 with a combined population of 400 million have officially achieved middle-income status.

But there are risks, with a fragile global economic recovery posing the greatest threat. A "hard landing" for the Chinese economy would adversely affect growth prospects. Over the past decade, sub-Saharan exports to China have risen from 5% to around 19.3% in 2010, with producers of oil (Sudan, Congo) and metal and mineral exporters (Zambia, Mauritania, the Democratic Republic of the Congo) among countries heavily dependent on Chinese appetite for commodities.

The report noted that oil-rich countries systematically perform worse than any other country groups in terms of voice and accountability, political stability, rule of law and the control of corruption. Chad and Sudan are the worst performers, according to the World Bank, and their governance indicators improved little between 2000-2010.

Anti-poverty campaigners have been pressing for more transparency and accountability in the natural resource sector as a way of putting pressure on governments. A focus of such efforts is the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative, which provides an internationally-recognised framework for public disclosure by mining companies and governments of what they pay and earn respectively. However, the initiative is voluntary, leaving implementation to those who sign up.

A European parliamentary committee last month approved a measure requiring EU oil, gas, mining and timber companies to publish their payments to foreign governments. The vote puts the world on track to create strong global transparency standards with equivalent rules in the EU and the US.

High Street banks need to step aside and allow community development finance institutions (CDFIs) to offer small-scale capital loans for SMEs and social enterprises, Lib Dem peer Baroness Kramer told the Community Development Finance Association (CDFA) conference in Solihull yesterday. "I have long taken the view frankly that for the high street banks, small businesses in vulnerable communities are just never going to be their client base", said Baroness Kramer. "I only just wish that they would say it".

During a session billed as 'How can banks and CDFIs work together...?', rather than working together Baroness Kramer appeared to suggest that each should know their separate role and get on with it. "The reality is that... [high street banks] certainly can't do relationship management for a micro business. One of the banks was very honest and direct with me and said 'any loan under £150,000 is going to be done by an algorithm, that's just the way it is – anything smaller than that, we are just not the appropriate institution to do customised relationship banking'. Well I wish they would say it to Treasury and to government, and that would enable them to get out of the way... To make sure [the CDFI] sector can move in and thrive and as a consequence the communities that you serve thrive."

In response, Irene Graham, managing director of business finance and strategy initiatives at the British Bankers Association, quoted the SME finance monitor that has found for the last four quarters that 7 out of 10 businesses have the right finance and are happy with the finance they have. Of those seeking finance through overdraft approvals, 90% are approved, said Graham. "For those businesses that aren't getting the finance that they need, there are some characteristics that are coming to the fore.

The characteristics are they are early-stage, start-up businesses, they don't necessarily have finance expertise in the company. Only 6% of businesses seek professional advice."

Similarly said Peter Ibbetson, chair of small business banking at RBS, the major high street banks "are lending about £100m to businesses every day and approving about nine out of ten applications for credit."

This rosy picture was not shared by many other conference speakers or delegates from the CDFI sector. Peter Holbrook, chief executive, Social Enterprise UK, said at a plenary session, "Are social enterprises financially excluded? The short answer is 'yes'... 44% say that their greatest barrier to growth and sustainability is access to capital. So we do clearly have a problem."

The bank-to-CDFI referral scheme to be jointly piloted by the CDFA and the British Bankers Association, however, was widely welcomed. Baroness Kramer described it as "a huge step forward". Jonathan Diggines, chair of the CDFA, told delegates there has been "a lot of talk about whether the banks are lending or not and if so how much.... [the referral scheme] is our chance to find out." He informed that the scheme is expected to work within the loan space of £50,000-70,000 whereby a rejected loan applicant will be automatically referred by the banks to the CDFA who will match them with potential CDFI funding.

From the big banks' perspective, Irene Graham suggested that if Baroness Kramer's wish is granted and banks to step out of small scale business finance, then they would happily step back in again once the business achieves scale. This could then offer the best of both worlds and an outline for what an effective partnership between banks and CDFIs could actually look like. "The national referral system ensures that the customer that isn't right for banking finance is given the automatic choice to be passed on to a CDFI", said Graham. "We hope that that creates a virtuous circle... and that business or social enterprise then ultimately comes back to the banking environment."

Tim Smedley is a freelance features writer for national newspapers and magazines, specialising in work, sustainability and social issues

Congestion with cars pulling up to drop children off and pick them up again is a daily problem for schools, not only causing issues for local residents but also contributing to global pollution.

And it is not only the health of the planet that is suffering. Air pollution, according to a report from the Policy Exchange, is second only to smoking as a public health risk.

This month sees the start of International Walk to School month, an initiative aimed at encouraging children to use their legs and get walking. Not just for the health benefits but also as a way to make pupils and parents more aware of the environmental benefits of walking to school.

School congestion has long been an issue for Mike Green, head teacher at Sunny Bank Primary School in Bury, Lancashire. But back in 2005 the school was one of the first in the area to have its travel plan approved by the local authority. Sunny Bank's travel plan was primarily designed to address issues surrounding congestion at peak times plus a lack of diversity in how children and parents travelled to school. It resulted in securing parking restrictions around the school and funding for a bike and scooter park on the site. The school has taken part in a number of WOW initiatives (Walk every Wednesday or Walk once a Week) supported by charity Living Streets.

Green said: "Since taking part in the WOW scheme, our school walking bus has been formed. The bus is driven by a stalwart group of parents and grandparents who pick up passengers at designated points on route. The route has been risk assessed by the local authority and the council agreed to the bus stops being marked out on the pavements. This led to our participation in the national Giant Walking Bus organised by the charity Brake.".

One of the main benefits for the school has been spin-offs into other environmental activities such as the Bike-It scheme run by Sustrans, which encourages children to cycle or scoot to school.

Green said: "Our Bike-It officer runs all sorts of events, including balance bike sessions or throw away your stabilizers day for the youngest children plus bike maintenance classes, supervised bike rides and things such as The Big Pedal, a round Britain virtual bike ride in which each cycle trip to school earns miles."

Teachers at a cluster of 12 schools in Hertfordshire have taken part in a new Walk to School initiative - one of them was Cuffley Primary School, Potter's Bar.

Year 6 teacher Alex Bedwell said the school had adopted some novel approaches to get pupils and parents to take a greener approach to the morning and afternoon school journeys. He said: "We developed an Advent walking bus so each child had a beautifully designed Advent calendar and each time they walked in they got a different tile for the calendar. That was very successful.

"As part of International Walk to School month, I organised for parents to be able to park in church car parks or in the youth centre car park and then I gave each child a passport. There were three main routes they could take to school and so I hid different country's flags for them to spot on their way in. That was great, although it did mean I was out at 5.30am on many mornings standing on my car poking flags into trees."

Bedwell says the advantages of the schemes are threefold for the school; reducing congestion around school, improving the social aspect of coming to school as children, parents and teachers get to chat on the way and promoting a greater awareness of how small steps taken locally could have an impact on the global environment.

Living Street's campaigns enjoy good success with primary schools - but what can teachers in secondary schools do to get their pupils walking?

At Boldon Secondary School, Boldon Colliery, the pupils have been taking part in a Free your Feet initiative. Assistant head teacher David Fairclough said: We held assemblies and talked about the health and environmental benefits of walking. They were all given diaries for the week of Free your Feet and so they could track how far they had walked. We tried to encourage them to do at least one day per week or at least come on their bikes. They got badges which became really popular and also at the end of it there was a reward of £50 for the person who had done the most miles."

He is pleased that the habit of walking and cycling has been seen to continue in the school and the school will focus on it for one week per year to try and bring its importance back to the fore.

"Parking is a perennial problem for us. It has a monumental impact on the school, roads and the environment. I wouldn't say we have solved the problem as we still have parents driving from less than half a mile away but the students are much more aware of the health and environmental impact of their choices."

No one becomes a sporting superstar alone. Behind them lies a legion of coaches, mentors and sports organisations. Likewise, development is a joint pursuit. Achieving public goals around education, health and other life-enhancing attributes requires a supporting infrastructure. So what happens when you bring the two together - sport and development - in genuine partnership?

That was the question Guardian Sustainable Business put to a panel of experts. Poised at their keyboards and ready for debate were: Tom Burstow, head of International Inspiration, UNICEF UK; Jon Long, head of executive programmes, International Cricket Council (ICC); John Shiels, chief executive, Manchester United Foundation; Ned Wills, director, Laureus Sport for Good Foundation; Tim Vine, head of public affairs, Premier League; and Simon White, managing director at Momentum UK.

Getting the basics straight

Sport for development. Does the idea even stack up? Right off the bat, the panel found itself defending the basic premise of the debate. Long at the ICC was first to the defence. He pointed to a "growing body of evidence" that proves the "social and financial return" on investing in sport for development. He specifically cited academics Aaron Smith and Hans Westerbeek, whose research highlights the unique ability of sports to generate social interaction, positive health impacts, cultural integration, and so on. Shiels of the Manchester United Foundation backed this up with the example of a football programme in Sierra Leone. Run in association with UNICEF and geared towards HIV/AIDS awareness, the initiative resulted in a 20% jump in condom use.

Despite this and many other positive examples, the panel conceded that evidence from the sport-for-development field had to move from the anecdotal to the empirical. "We do need to better communicate sport and its value, not just describing a generic benefit or catch all that sport is just great", admitted UNICEF's Burstow. ICC's Long was equally frank about the problem. Inputs are much easier to capture than outputs, he conceded, "particularly when working across a range of markets, cultures and languages". However, Wills at Laureus Sport for Good Foundation insisted progress is being made around impact measurement. He points to InFocus, a bespoke system co-developed by Laureus for project management and global data collection. The system works by identifying output objectives up front, "searching for evidence of those outcomes" and then aggregating these across a range of programmes.

Establishing sound partnerships

The question of measurement is important, but it jumps the gun somewhat. If you're to measure impacts, you need to generate them first. And that requires effective partnerships. What do such partnerships look like? Vine of the Premier League pointed to two fundamental factors. One, find a partner that has reach. Two, find partners with local know-how. For the first, the Premier League turned to the British Council, which counts offices in over 100 countries. For the second, it identified a range of NGOs with "vast experience on the ground" - Right to Play in Africa, for instance, or the Rafa Marquz Foundation in Mexico. ICC's Long agreed that choosing an umbrella organisation with local expertise and "bona-fide" networks is essential. In ICC's case, UNICEF fitted that bill. "With limited resource, it is pointless trying to re-invent the wheel", he argued. "It is far better to work with experts and recognised best in field."

Building a business case

Panelists also stressed the importance of mutual learning and shared benefits. "The resources of large sporting organisations are of course invaluable for development programmes", said a contributor from StreetFootballWorld, "but the real benefit is in the exchange of knowledge and experience." Wills felt Laureus' Coach Across America programme with Mercedes Benz illustrates that point exactly. The automaker has its eye on the next generation of car buyers. By working with youth in under-served communities in the US, it is "talking now to [its] future customers". Clearly there needs to be a business incentive for companies to get involved, otherwise it all comes down to the whims of "the Chairman's chequebook", said Long. Firms need to consider what media coverage they might gain, for example, or what employee or product benefits might emerge. "It can sound a bit brutal but at the end of the day, unless the company is indulging the chairman's passion, it will boil down to a business decision", Long spelt out. Not that philanthropy isn't important. The Premier League's Vine was keen to rebuff the "misconception" that football clubs only invested in youth programmes so as to find the next Didier Drogba. Clubs and players genuinely want to help young people play football or gain an education, he said.

Leaving a lasting legacy

A number of readers voiced about financial sustainability. What happens when the funding finishes? With the focus now squarely on sport and "social legacy", it's a legitimate question. "Chucking a few free T-shirts and some signed photos around is NOT the way to go", White at Momentum UK stressed. While it was widely agreed that sport-stars can bring kudos and coverage to development projects, White urged against "shallow engagement" that relies too heavily on "the fame of sport". Better, said ICC's Shiels, to ensure that long-term building blocks are in place. That means stadia and sports facilities, of course. But it also means competent local personnel. As he put it: "In many instances we would like to train local people, so that if and when funding stops we have people in place locally to take it on."

Lessons can also be learned from International Inspiration, the London 2012 Olympics' primary legacy programme. So said Burstow of UNICEF, which is heavily involved in the initiative. Where short-term impacts mature into long-term outcomes is when government gets involved, he argued. For that reason, UNICEF is working with town and city mayors in Brazil ahead of the 2014 World Cup and 2016 Olympics to encourage them to invest in "opportunities for sport and play". Vine of the Premier League reinforced the point. The League's flagship Premier Skills project seeks to involve the ministries of youth, education and sport wherever possible. "It is important that Govts [sic] understand the work we are delivering, and hopefully feel compelled to build on what we have started." Oh, and don't forget to involve young people themselves. "Rigid" and "inflexible" projects "set up by a load of 'suits' with little understanding" won't go the distance, Vine warned. "Much better that the youngsters involved are at the heart of it, feel ownership of it, and become key people in driving it forward."

Updated 9.45am Saturday: Despite The Guardian publishing an obituary on Sunday of the journalistic campaigner Crispin Aubrey, his death at the age of 66 has received too little coverage.

He featured in one of the more bizarre episodes in the chequered history of the use/misuse of the official secrets act (OSA) against journalists.

Under that act, Aubrey - then working for Time Out magazine covering the environment and nuclear energy - was arrested in February 1977 along with Duncan Campbell, a freelance investigative journalist, and John Berry, a social worker who had once been a corporal in signals intelligence (SigInt).

The three had been drawn together in their opposition to the deportation orders made against another Time Out journalist, Mark Hosenball, and a former CIA agent, Philip Agee.

Hosenball (jointly with Campbell) had written an exposé of GCHQ, the government's communications headquarters in Cheltenham, and he was considered by the then Labour government to be a threat to national security, as was Agee who had written a book called Inside the Company: CIA Diary.

Aubrey mounted a campaign on behalf of his colleague against the deportations and was joined by Campbell - who had wide and detailed knowledge of covert surveillance techniques - and Berry.

The three were arrested by special branch as they left Berry's flat and held in Brixton prison. Aubrey and Campbell were charged under section 2 of the OSA with the unauthorised receipt of classified information; Berry was charged with giving it to them.

Their homes were searched, and Campbell's flat in Brighton, close to where I lived, was ransacked, as I witnessed at first hand. So, when he was bailed, he took shelter with my wife and I for a couple of weeks.

What transpired was one of the more farcical episodes of an affair that, in retrospect, can be seen as a fiasco. Our Brighton home was already under watch from the special branch because my wife had been visiting an Irish republican prisoner.

Now a second branch man was detailed to keep tabs on Campbell. We joked that we had one at the front of the house and another at the back.

The following year Aubrey, Berry and Campbell appeared in court in what was known as the ABC trial (an acronym of their surnames). By that time, the three had been lionised by the left and a defence campaign had been launched with the solid backing of the National Union of Journalists.

There was considerable disquiet about the trio being prosecuted at all and then further alarm when Campbell was also accused of breaching section 1 of the OSA.

More controversy followed when the government produced SigInt witnesses known as Colonel A, Colonel B, and Mr C. Two weeks in, the trial had to be abandoned.

The defence discovered that the jury foreman was a former SAS officer and that two other jurors had signed the official secrets act. The judge initially refused to stop the trial on those grounds but was forced to do so when the late Christopher Hitchens appeared on television to reveal the secret of the jury's composition.

At the second trial, a new judge, Mr Justice Mars-Jones, announced himself "extremely unhappy" at what he called an "oppressive prosecution". The section 1 charge was dropped and though the three had no defence to the section 2 charges, he gave Berry a suspended jail sentence and conditionally discharged Aubrey and Campbell. They had been expecting to go to prison.

After the trial, Aubrey wrote a book entitled Who's Watching You? Britain's Security Service and the Officials Secrets Act, which was published in 1981.

He went on being a journalist, remained steadfastly true to his principles and continued being an anti-nuclear campaigner right up until his death last Friday (28 September) at his home in Somerset. He was due to speak at next weekend's Stop Hinckley campaign rally.

For the record, Philip Agee died in 2008. Mark Hosenball continued in journalism and now works for Reuters, which occasionally brings him to London. He has broken several stories about the News International phone hacking affair.

Duncan Campbell lives in Brighton - I bumped into him during the summer - and he remains an investigative journalist with a penchant for upsetting the establishment.

UPDATE: In the original version of this posting I said I had no idea what happened to John Berry. I am happy to report that he and his partner Linda moved to the same patch of Somerset as Crispin and his wife, Sue, and continued their work as social workers. They are still there.

This information comes from Duncan Campbell (not the one mentioned above, but the former Guardian staffer who also happened to be news editor of Time Out at the time of the ABC case and who, incidentally, wrote Crispin's obituary).

He tells me that when the ABC trio first appeared before magistrates, he made a statement on their behalf outside the court. A picture of him duly appeared on the front page of The Scotsman inevitably mistaking him for his arrested namesake.

The caption read: "Duncan Campbell who faces charges under the Official Secrets Act. His widowed mother lives in Dundee." It was a shock at breakfast for his mother and father who lived in The Scotsman's home city of Edinburgh.

The actor Daryl Hannah was arrested in northeast Texas on Thursday, along with a landowner as the pair protested against an oil pipeline designed to bring crude from Canada to the Gulf Coast.

"They've arrested Daryl Hannah and a rural Texas great-grandmother," said Paul Bassis, Hannah's attorney.

Hannah and Eleanor Fairchild were standing in front of heavy equipment in an attempt to halt construction of the Keystone XL pipeline on Fairchild's farm in Winnsboro, a town about 100 miles east of Dallas. They were arrested for criminal trespassing and taken to the Wood County Jail, Bassis said.

Hannah has long opposed TransCanada's construction of the $7bn pipeline, which is designed to transport heavy tar-sands crude oil from Alberta, Canada, to Texas' Gulf Coast refineries.

"It is unfortunate Ms Hannah and other out-of-state activists have chosen to break the law by illegally trespassing on private property," David Dodson, a spokesman for TransCanada, said in a statement. He also said protesters were "putting their own safety and the safety of others at risk".

Hannah – who has starred in dozens of movies, including Kill Bill and Splash – also was arrested in August 2011 while protesting against the pipeline in Washington. She was one of several hundred prominent scientists and activists arrested that month.

They argue the pipeline would be unsafe because it would be carrying heavy, acidic crude oil that could more easily corrode a metal pipe, which would lead to a spill. They also say refining the oil would further contaminate the air in a region that has long struggled with pollution.

TransCanada says its pipeline would be the safest ever built, and that the crude is no dirtier than oil currently arriving from Venezuela or parts of California.

The issue became politically charged when congressional Republicans gave President Barack Obama 60 days to decide whether TransCanada should be granted the necessary permit for the pipeline to cross an international border before snaking its way 1,700 miles south to the Texas coast.

Obama, saying his administration did not have enough time to study the potential environmental impacts, denied the permit in January.

However, he encouraged TransCanada to reroute the northern portion of the pipeline to avoid an environmentally sensitive area of Nebraska. He also promised to expedite permitting of a southern portion of the pipeline from Cushing, Oklahoma, to the Gulf Coast to relieve a bottleneck at the Cushing refinery.

TransCanada began construction of that portion of the pipeline this summer after receiving the necessary permits. Some Texas landowners, joined by activists from outside the state, have tried through various protests to stop or slow down construction.

Say what you like about Ed Miliband, but the guy's got chutzpah. His claim that Labour is now the country's "one nation party" was hardly original: Tony Blair said exactly the same thing back in February 1995. Still, it has caught the imagination of the media and may even cut through to the electorate. If it does, however, the Tories only have themselves to blame. Miliband, like Blair before him, is simply exploiting a gaping hole left at the heart of the Conservative party by the virtual disappearance of the Tory left.

In an essay for the Institute for Public Policy Research journal Juncture, I argue that the so-called progressive, "one-nation", Tories constituted the parliamentary party's centre of gravity from the 50s through to the mid-70s. For these Tories, mass unemployment was not only economically irrational but morally indefensible. The welfare state and mixed economy was a necessary, even welcome corrective to market failure and trade unionism a power that needed channelling rather than crushing.

Socially, a degree of multiculturalism was an inevitable legacy of Britain's imperial past that may as well be embraced rather than railed against. Prison worked, but law and order had to be about prevention and rehabilitation, too. Comprehensive schooling and mass higher education (though rarely good enough for their own children) was more likely than a divisively selective and elitist system to help the UK compete in a rapidly Europeanising economy.

It was these views – maintained partly out of conviction, partly out of calculation – that prompted many of the U-turns that helped ensure that the initially rather rightwing Heath administration ended up as the government most Tories love to hate. Yet progressives might have retained control of the party after the election defeats of 1974 had they handled its aftermath more adroitly. By not insisting their beleaguered leader step down in favour of a trusted successor, however, they allowed Margaret Thatcher – a woman they badly underestimated – to mount what turned out to be one of the most effective insurgencies in British political history. Before they knew it, she was handing over the key policy portfolios to fellow rightwingers and beginning to shunt those she saw as irredeemable patricians into the sidings.

After 1979, a combination of Thatcher's stunning electoral success and generational replacement within the parliamentary party – plus the increasingly poisonous politics of Europe – meant that even those leftwingers whose talent made them individually indispensable (Ken Clarke being the paradigmatic example) quickly found themselves fewer and farther between. As a result, while the Tories may have dumped Thatcher in 1990, they have never managed to dump Thatcherism.

There were some who believed that David Cameron would finally help them do so. But as leader of the opposition, Cameron never really had any of the big arguments with his party that anyone driving genuine change needs to have – not so much because he was scared to, but because, once one scratched away their social liberalism and their affected concern for the environment and public services, he and those around him were no less Thatcherite than the rest.

Because there was no transformation towards post-Thatcherism, let alone pre-Thatcherism, Cameron as prime minister now finds himself faced with a party in parliament and a party in the media which borders on the delusional – unable to accept that simply swallowing more and more of the medicine once prescribed by their heroine might not do the job this time around. More pressingly, the gap between the Tories and the Lib Dems is proving much bigger than creative thinkers on the Conservative side, such as Nick Boles, hoped that it might be – precisely because the number of his Conservative colleagues ideologically willing and able to reach across it proved vanishingly small.

The most important gap, however, is the one that the shock-troops of "one-nation Labour" (presuming for the moment they are more than a phantom army) look set to pour into, namely the gap between what a 21st century electorate want from a Tory government – a blend of competence and compassion, willing to take on vested interests in the private as well as the public sector in order to show that we really are "all in this together" – and what they are currently getting.

The problem for the Tories is that there are so few of them who understand this. Because the party's left failed to recover from the extinction-level event that hit it in 1975, there is no way the pendulum can swing back.

Back before Disraeli, another Tory icon Edmund Burke reminded reactionaries that "a state without the means of some change is without the means of its conservation". The same goes for a political party. Without a genuine balance of forces that ensures the presence of people prepared to challenge the prevailing wisdom, a damaging groupthink can develop, blinkering the majority that buys into it into believing that there is no alternative.

Occasionally, of course, they are right. But if they are wrong, the results can be disastrous.

Over the course of the past seven years, I have become closely acquainted with international anti-corruption conventions and know a thing or two about multilateral anti-corruption instruments.

The Open Government Partnership stands out because of its focus on citizens. By 2011, something that started life in late 2009 as a US directive, urging all US executive departments and agencies to pursue transparency, enable participation and collaboration and improve communication with citizens, had become a multilateral initiative supported by eight countries. It is now a community of 57 member countries committed to implementing these aims for their 2 billion citizens.

Citizens are to be consulted in the development of new OGP commitments, and they are to be empowered in the quest for transparency, accountability and improved governance. So yes, the enthusiasm the OGP has managed to garner in a relatively short amount of time is warranted.

However, there are still some potential pitfalls that we must consider.

First, it is likely that citizens of many of the participating countries are not aware of the initiative and consequently cannot make the most of it. Will this influence the UK, new co-chair of the OGP, to work hard over the next 12 months towards communicating the opportunities of open government?

Second, the romantic belief that everyone will want to take part in policy-making and other political processes, if and when technology makes it simpler or more effective, does not necessarily hold true. Most countries, whether or not they form part of the OGP community, haveapathetic citizens. For example, an online petition in Germany did not bring about dramatic change in democratic participation and citizen engagement. As US history and politics lecturer Matthew Lasar has noted, it is the already politically engaged who tend to embrace these sort of tools, not the disengaged.

We hope that an e-petition platform soon to be launched in Montenegro will not share the same fate.

There are practical difficulties, too. Open data portals may be a valuable source of information, but they are not really the first web page an ordinary citizen visits over their morning coffee. Large screens full of .xsl tables can seem daunting and unintelligible.

For open data to reach its full potential to help people monitor government performance or make informed choices on the use of public services, data must be put in a context and should tell a story people can care about. I fell in love with the tale of citizens overseeing a public-private partnership in Brussels, which was about access to bike-sharing schemes.

There needs to be engagement around data, and many, many iterations based on feedback loops to get it right and effect a change in behaviour – just as this down-to-earth use of open data mappublic toilets in the UK did. But my favourite application, by far, is this visualisation of public budgets: Where does my money go? We liked this so much that we are also about to visualise Montenegro's national budget.

Third, the OGP lacks a set of standards against which progress in the participating countries can be measured. The monitoring mechanism is still to be proven effective, though admittedly the OGP has been much more agile in setting it up than, say, the Conference of States Parties to the UN Convention against corruption. We want to see a change in lives and a change to citizens' interaction with their governments – which is the ultimate point – and such goals are far from easy in the short term.

Let's hope that the new chairmanship, boosted by the launch of the independent review mechanism, the independent process that allows domestic civil society in each OGP country to report on their government's implementation of its OGP action plan, will steer the OGP effectively and cast away some of the doubts about OGP staffing and vision expressed in some recent posts by NGO Global Integrity.

Jim Murphy is one of the many senior Labour figures to have begun his political career as president of the National Union of Students. During his mid-90s tenure there, he dropped – against the union's own conference resolutions – all opposition to the abolition of student grants, helping to ensure that in future an education would come at the cost of crippling debt and insecurity. When reading the following, bear this in mind.

"My biggest priority in politics," the shadow defence secretary said this week, "is about working-class parents having middle-class kids. I want parents to have the chance to bring up kids who do better than them." On the face of it, this is a normal centre-left response to the very real decline of social mobility, however much that decline might have been assisted by Murphy's tenure at the NUS. It's given some additional pertinence by Labour's admission that currently the next generation will be worse off than their parents. An "inherited poverty", as Murphy puts it, now stands in the way of young working-class people's "aspirations".

The details are pretty light on the ground, but given the lack of much change in Labour's ideas about education – after all, it commissioned the Browne report that trebled tuition fees and proposed 100% cuts to arts funding – we can expect the solution to be the debt, marketisation and expansion that were New Labour education policy. Sotto voce, there's something else going on here – the explicit abandonment of the idea that, for the labour movement, you "rise with your class, not out of it".

Rising out of your class can lead to all manner of things. Kicking away the ladder after you've climbed up, as working-class Glaswegian Murphy did as a student leader; or the kind of up-by-the-bootstraps rightwing individualism that Norman Tebbit specialised in; or, at best, an acknowledgement that your privilege and success are deeply unusual and unrepresentative.

My father is a middle manager at a software company. He left school at 14 and worked as a sheet metal worker (as had his father) for most of the next 30 years, becoming shop steward and then convener, and a Labour, or rather Militant, activist. He read, and reads, voraciously, in history, politics and economics, everything from Marx to Thucydides, to the point where he's far more erudite than many people I know who went to university. This didn't make him "socially mobile", at least not until he finally got sick of bending pieces of metal every day and sought a promotion off the shop floor. The working class was no longer showing much signs of rising; so he rose out of it, at least in economic terms.

Later I did the same, through the conventional route of university. A decade or so after that my mother followed suit, going via a job in the NHS from a council estate single mum to a qualified radiologist. In theory we are all marvellous success stories of social mobility. So why does Murphy's rhetoric make me feel so uncomfortable?

What made all of us able to rise out of our class was a culture based on the class rising collectively. The culture of the Labour movement – its literature, its debates, its prizing of learning as a means of struggle, its insistence that "knowledge is power" – is what made my parents educate themselves in the first place. Being brought up in that environment, being unafraid of books and intellectual argument, meant that I had the confidence to cope easily with the very different intellectual culture of university, without being intimidated by its privilege.

Those books in the shelves at home – EP Thompson's Making of the English Working Class, say, or Lenin's What is to be Done? – were about the class, as a collectively organised body, educating itself and advancing itself, with the aim of abolishing itself and creating a society without classes, something both my parents once thought they might live to see. We used that culture of knowledge and self-education for advancement into a different class. We did well. The working class as a whole very obviously didn't, as the culture that helped us up had been deliberately destroyed. For my parents especially, it was at the very least a pyrrhic victory.

Labour has never, even in its more leftwing moments, been that concerned about abolishing class altogether, though some of its leaders might once have kidded themselves that "we are all middle class now", something hard to sustain as the gap between rich and poor became ever more drastic. They did promise a reform of the class structure, so that there was at least "equality of opportunity" between classes, something that has been honoured more in the breach.

As the labour movement, with its own educational institutions, becomes more distant from the Labour party, it can only dangle the hope for individual self-advancement – the chance that you, too, could get on in the rat race. Murphy might remember the words of another Scottish politician, Jimmy Reid, who used to like to walk around Glasgow tower blocks and point out how in one there was a Formula One champion and in another the winner of a yacht race – who would never get the chance to sit at the wheel of a racing car or a yacht.

But Murphy, and Labour as a whole, have long forgotten his other point, made in his famous 1972 speech to Glasgow University – that "the rat race is for rats". Reid continued: "Reject the insidious pressures in society that would blunt your critical faculties to all that is happening around you, that would caution silence in the face of injustice lest you jeopardise your chances of promotion and self-advancement. This is how it starts, and, before you know where you are, you're a fully paid-up member of the rat pack. The price is too high." Around £9,000 a year, to be precise.

I drag myself out of bed about 7.30am, grab some porridge with honey and bananas for breakfast and – if I'm in university that day – walk to campus, which is about two minutes away.

I will have university one day a week and placement the other four days this year, now I'm in my second year. The day that I'm in university will be quite a long day – 8.30am until 4-5pm.

Everyone has a different placement. Some are quite similar. Last year I was working at a children's centre, under-fives and their families. That was quite good. I don't know my placement for this year yet. But it will be less university time and more placement time. There's a real emphasis on more practical learning.

Lectures can be an hour or two. Personally, I really enjoy the ethics and body language and communication is the sort of stuff I'm really interested in. But everyone has their own preference. I know some people enjoy the law part; I don't like that – it's a bit dry.

I'm at the University of Plymouth. We have six learning themes throughout the social work course. These consist of "approaches to social work"; "contexts for social work"; "understanding the social world"; "values, attitudes and beliefs"; "wellbeing and social work"; and "what is social work?" However, later in the course "understanding the social world", "values attitudes and beliefs" and "what is social work?" are integrated within teaching and will not feature as weekly teaching sessions.

Relevant law and policy will also be covered, and there is a strong emphasis on the global perspective, as well a local and national one. There is also an emphasis of the service user being the expert.

I usually grab lunch on campus. It's good because me and my course mates usually go to lectures together, then hang around to have lunch together. I think that's when a lot of real learning happens – when you're discussing what you've been taught.

There is 56 people in my year group, with only eight men. In the previous years we have had practical sessions and also share learning experiences from practice during our tutor sessions. The university also arranges conferences and attending these are mandatory.

We have assignments in which we must incorporate all learning themes, and often critically explore our practice. We also have an OSPA (observed simulated practice assessment) in which we receive information, video clips and audio clips of a fictional referral to social service. We must then complete an initial assessment under exam conditions. I usually stay on campus to do work. Last year I went back home, but it's too noisy to do work where I am now.

I usually unwind on my Xbox, but I also like rock climbing. There's quite a good social life in Plymouth. Obviously, because we're on placement and we have a lot on at university we don't go out as much as other students – it's not really a party course. But we do have the weekends ...

I decided to study social work because I was working as a refrigerator engineer – and I hated it because I was working with machines, and I didn't really care. I wanted to work with people.

I think I want to go into child protection for a little while. I hear that there's a high burnout rate so not for too long though. I'm not sure what area I'll want to go into afterwards.

If I was to give advice to social work students, I would say it's really, really hard and it's a lot of work. But it's really rewarding too, so I think if you're going to go into it then you have to do it whole-heartedly.

I don't sleep very well, so I usually go to bed after 2am. The last thing I usually think about is that I should be asleep already.

After a series of personal tragedies, Derek Langford hit rock bottom last year – he suffered a breakdown, took solace in drink and finally, attempted to take his own life.

Mercifully, the pills did not work and he found his way – via his community psychiatric nurse – to a Green Gym near his home in Birmingham's Sandwell neighbourhood. The project, designed to improve people's mental and physical wellbeing through their involvement in conservation activities and run by The Conservation Volunteers (TCV), has renewed his zest for life.

"I really was a total mess," admits Langford, 43, a former tarmacker. "For months I just sat there, drinking – I just couldn't get out of it. I'm still living day by day, but overall I'm now in a much better place."

Since last June, Langford has attended the Green Gym twice a week – frequently taking part in off-site activities such as dry-stone walling and hedge-laying and sometimes helping out at educational events for young people. He has made new friends and developed an appreciation of the importance of the environment.

Along the way, he attended training courses and has now been made a team leader, with responsibilities which include carrying out risk assessments on new project sites. Separately, in the evenings, he also started volunteering with a local homeless project.

Green Gym is just one of the initiatives run by TCV, a charity which works to reclaim and protect green spaces across the UK. Most of its practical projects take place on other people's land – National Trust sites, for example, or local authority parks or school grounds. Many of TCV's participants – or volunteers, as the charity prefers to call them – have additional needs, for example through disability, mental illness or a history of substance abuse.

The Hollybush Centre in Kirkstall, Leeds, has been running for 30 years, and is part way through a four-year grant from the Big Lottery Fund. Working closely with Leeds Mind, the NHS and, sometimes organisations in the housing or social sectors, it sends volunteers to build pocket parks and recreation spaces, remove invasive species and repair walls on the Pennine moors. It also offers gardening and cooking sessions for those less happy to go out in the minibus.

Individuals can be referred by services such as drug and alcohol support, Mencap, hospital occupational therapy and job centres, as well as self-referrals.

Increasingly, staff are trying to gauge participants' interests and moving them towards employment, and this year they started working with Leeds Community Healthcare – formerly the PCT – to encourage volunteers who want help tackling their alcohol use, smoking or weight problems.

In turn, GPs and other clinicians may suggest that patients consider volunteering with TCV as a means of increasing their activity levels.

Hollybush manager John Preston says: "In any given group you might see people with a brain injury, someone with a sensory impairment such as deafness, and people with profound cognitive impairments, who may struggle to remember things.

"Some of our volunteers can be very isolated – we sometimes become a key part of people's social and even family life in some ways, because of the amount of time they spend here."

Preston says those in the organisation often develop good relationships, because volunteers turn to them when they are in distress "because they know us."

"When one long-standing volunteer who had mental health and alcohol issues suffered a relapse but was refusing to go to A&E, we were able to intervene, make contact with that person's partner and bring the problem under control," he says. "People come here and we give them the space to do things. We try to give them more responsibilities – in time they may end up running a group."

The centre's 12 staff rely on a team of voluntary supervisors or "key volunteers" to help run their activities; attendees who have been promoted, retired people and sometimes social care students. In time, Preston also hopes to develop an evening "friends of" group, which would allow volunteers who have moved on to maintain a relationship with TCV and their peers.

Encouraging individuals to take on more responsibility can have a huge impact on their lives. Preston fondly recalls one volunteer who, before arriving at Hollybush, had barely left his home for four years because he was horribly bullied at work. After a stint of volunteering, the same man was able to get up and speak to TCV's national board of directors. He recently began a two-day-a-week diploma course and is now searching for part-time work.

Back in Birmingam, Langford is also acutely aware of the value of this approach. "The people who run the Green Gym have a lot of faith in me and see my potential," he says. "I had lost faith in myself but my confidence has come back up and I now have the will to live again."

Samsung Electronics says it will report a record quarterly operating profit of 8.1tn Korean won (£4.5bn), nearly double last year's and up 25% sequentially, as strong sales of high-end TVs and Galaxy smartphones more than offset reduced orders for chips and screens from Apple, its main rival and leading customer.

The figure covers the three months to the end of September. Most analysts, however, expect its run of four straight record quarters to end in December as the South Korean group, the world's leading maker of smartphones, TVs and memory chips, ramps up its marketing to counter Apple's new iPhone and other products in the increasingly crowded and competitive $200bn (£123.5bn) global smartphone market.

The operating profit figure is an estimate provided by Samsung itself in an earnings preview. That beat the consensus from a poll of 26 analysts, who pegged it at 7.6tn won, up from 4.25tn a year ago.

Samsung may have spent around $2.7bn on marketing in July-September alone around the London Olympic Games, for which it was a major sponsor, and new Galaxy promotions, Credit Suisse has estimated.

This year's expected record profit of 28tn won will also trigger higher performance-related payouts to many of Samsung's 206,000 staff early next year. The business may have to set money aside in the current quarter if it fails in an appeal to overturn a US court verdict from August which awarded more than $1bn in damages to Apple for patent infringements on phones and tablets.

"Fourth-quarter profit will be pressured by one-off expenses: performance payouts and some $1bn in legal provisioning relating to the Apple litigation. Excluding those, core earnings will remain solid and a swing factor is how much Samsung spends on marketing," said Lee Sun-tae, analyst at NH Investment & Securities.

Analysts expect earnings to decline until the second quarter of next year as a slump in computer sales and a weak global economy sap demand for chips and electronics products.

Smartphone tightrope

"The biggest risk for Samsung is competitive product line-ups from its rivals such as the iPhone 5. Because handsets drive most of its profits, one misstep in handsets could result in losses for the whole Samsung group," said Byun Han-joon, an analyst at KB Investment & Securities.

So far though, there is no sign of that happening, with its former key rivals – Finland's Nokia, Taiwan's HTC and Motorola in the US – falling behind in both profits and shipments.

Profit at Samsung's mobile division is likely to have more than doubled in July-September to around 5tn won – around two thirds of total group profit – as smartphone shipments are estimated to have topped 58m, including up to 20m Galaxy S IIIs. Samsung does not give figures for its shipments of smartphones, mobile phones or tablets, which are instead estimated by analysts.

The company, valued at around $197bn, estimated its third-quarter revenue at 52tn won, in line with forecasts.

Chips, cheaply?

Strong handset sales compensated for reduced profits from its chip business, as prices of its mainstay dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chips, used in computers and mobiles, dropped 14% in the September quarter. DRAM chips now trade below what it costs most contract manufacturers to make them, and will squeeze near-term earnings, analysts say.

Tablets and smartphones, the real growth areas, use far less storage. Samsung is expected to invest less in chips next year due to the drop in demand, which could be bad news for semiconductor equipment manufacturers such as ASML.

Kwon Oh-hyun, promoted to Samsung CEO in June, said late last month that the group has yet to finalise its 2013 investment plans.

Samsung is beefing up its product line-up, with the latest phone-cum-tablet Galaxy Note expected to go on sale in the US this month, and its ATIV smartphones that run on Microsoft's new Windows system to compete with Nokia's Lumia series.

Note-taking

Samsung's mobile division chief, JK Shin last, week predicted that sales of its large-screen Galaxy Note II could be three times higher than those of its predecessor model in the three months after launch. That would suggest sales of around 10m devices by the end of this year.

Some analysts see the Note II, along with a stripped-down, cheaper version of the flagship Galaxy S III smartphone and rising NAND flash memory chip prices helping Samsung deliver higher fourth-quarter profit. Nomura on Friday predicted October-December profit could be up to 10% more than the 8.1tn won in July-September.

In a note on Friday, Citi analyst Henry Kim predicted strong October-December profits, driven by a recovery in semiconductors, though telecoms operating margins could decline by 5 percentage points to 15% as it spends more on marketing. "The semiconductor division will show the strongest momentum," he said.

Despite a bruising series of patent disputes and the reputational risk of the US court defeat in August, Samsung's brand value has surged this year as it shipped more handsets and smartphones than any of its rivals. The value of the Samsung brand has jumped to 9th in the world – up from 17th last year – at $32.9bn, according to brand consultancy Interbrand. That's more than Toyota Motor, but less than half of second-ranked Apple's $76.6bn.

This year is the bicentennial of the first publication of a work that WH Auden described as one of "the few indispensable, common-property books upon which western culture can be founded" and "next to the Bible in importance". It also gave us the fictional character with the highest name recognition in the English language, Cinderella (although in 1812, when the book was published in German, the name she had was Ashputtel). The book is Kinder- und Hausmärchen (more commonly known as Grimms' Fairy Tales) by Jacob and Wilhelm Grimm.

So it is unsurprising and, indeed, proper that Penguin Classics should produce a new collection of the tales for this Christmas. And frankly, once you have arrived at this point, Philip Pullman is a shoo-in for the task, because he writes the most limpid, economic narrative prose; because he is already famous for dealing in magical realms (though a very different sort of magic); and, above all perhaps, because he is one of the very few contemporary writers who has written genuine cross-generational fiction. The Grimm Brothers did not set out to record children's stories, and all the anthropological evidence suggests that until well into the 19th century these kinds of oral folk tales were not specifically for children but for everyone. This is nicely reflected in Pullman's subtitle – "for young and old".

Pullman has chosen and retold his 50 favourites from the original stories – 50 out of more than 200 means, inevitably, that your own favourites may very well have been omitted. Where is the delightful "White Snake" and its charming young servant hero? How could anyone prefer the rambling "Twelve Brothers" to the very similar but obviously better "Six Swans", with its heroine who laboriously makes shirts out of starwort? But Pullman's selection is fair and wide ranging and embraces most of the types of story. If it is distinctly thin on the more pious tales, that is hardly surprising. Given his well-known views on religion it would prove well nigh impossible to present "The Three Green Twigs" or "Poverty and Humility Lead to Heaven" as personal favourites. And if any of the stories are going to vanish, these are probably the ones in which there is currently least interest and engagement; even "pious types" such as me would not want to lose "Cinderella" or "Rumpelstiltskin" in favour of "The Hazel Branch" or the macabre "God's Food".

One of the best things that Pullman does in his all-too-short introduction is reiterate the oral tradition from which these stories come – from a writer's point of view, this means that, though you need to be respectful, you do not need to venerate any pre-existing text. The Grimms themselves did not, adding and subtracting details as their audience demanded (they have been much criticised for this, I have always felt, unfairly; they honoured the tradition of the tales precisely by adapting them to new audiences). Pullman does this with great elegance, for example strangling the husband in "The Three Snake Leaves", instead of just chucking him overboard, so that the readers or hearers know he is genuinely dead and so that the rope is available as evidence at the denouement: this really does make the narrative stronger.

Elaborating Cinderella's ballgowns into the colours of starlight, moonlight and sunlight (rather than the simpler gold and silver of the Grimms' version) enhances the sense of magic, while allowing her to choose these colours herself reduces her passivity and demonstrates her good taste. One of Pullman's most useful additions is the vastly improved poems and jingles, which are hard to translate closely. His freer versions are catchy and authentic.

However, his willingness to write like a storyteller, giving us his own versions of the stories, makes his expressed desire to keep himself back, to create a voice as "clear as water" and focus solely on the story rather than a personal interpretation, seem like a contradiction. He writes too well, there is clarity and energy on almost every page, but it is Pullman as clear as a bell.

One thing I found fascinating, though strange: he praises the generality and economy of the Grimms' tales and the lack of specificity and description, yet he adds a great deal of detail (none of his versions is shorter than the original, except where he has deliberately omitted narrative digressions). Perhaps written texts require more detail than oral versions, in which expression and gesture can supply nuance.

This collection is issued as a "classic", so it is probably right to aim for a style free of the gothic extravagance of Angela Carter or the contemporary ethics of Jane Yolen or any other highly literary or individual interpretation, but for those who already know the stories this results in a collection which is very good, but not very interesting. If I were choosing a collection for someone – a child, perhaps – who did not know any of the tales, I would still opt for Jack Zipes's lively translation of the whole oeuvre, The Complete Fairy Tales, partly because my favourites (and yours and everyone's) will be there, and partly because it seems a more straightforward and comfortable enterprise.
